headline.main: AN ELECTRONIC BYPASS IS PERFORMED IN SPACE WALK

results.snippet: Two space-walking astronauts plucked a disabled 15,000-pound satellite out of orbit today and, working with the agility of tree surgeons and the skill of electricians, performed an electronic bypass operation in an ingenious attempt to bring the...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Two space-walking astronauts plucked a disabled 15,000-pound satellite out of orbit today and, working with the agility of tree surgeons and the skill of electricians, performed an electronic bypass operation in an ingenious attempt to bring the satellite back to life. But, as expected, the slow performance of the space shuttle Discovery's mechanical arm prevented the astronauts from completing the job. They plan another excursion outside the cabin Sunday morning to wrap up the repairs and redeploy the satellite. At a news conference at the Johnson Space Center in Houston after the repair maneuvers, William Reeves, a flight director, said: ''We had an extremely successful day. But we have another tough day ahead of us.''

headline.main: SPACEWALKING ASTRONAUTS REPAIR SATELLITE AND SPIN IT OFF ON MISSION

results.snippet: Leaning forward from the end of the space shuttle's mechanical arm, like the figurehead on the prow of an old sailing ship, Dr. James D. van Hoften today gave the rewired Leasat 3 satellite a vigorous shove and sent it spinning away with a new...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Leaning forward from the end of the space shuttle's mechanical arm, like the figurehead on the prow of an old sailing ship, Dr. James D. van Hoften today gave the rewired Leasat 3 satellite a vigorous shove and sent it spinning away with a new chance at a useful life in higher orbit. ''There that bad boy goes,'' the astronaut said as he watched the departing 15,000-pound satellite, sunlight glinting off the solar cells that cover its exterior. The successful redeployment of the communications satellite came at the end of the second space walk in two days by Dr. van Hoften and Dr. William F. Fisher of the space shuttle Discovery. They spent four and a half hours outside the cabin today, completing the repairs begun in an arduous seven-hour operation Saturday.

headline.main: SANDINISTA PORTRAIT: POET, MILITANT, BIBLE DEVOTEE

results.snippet: Tomas Borge, the Nicaraguan Interior Minister, is a man of many public identities. Sometimes he appears in battle fatigues. Other times, he is dressed as a policeman. At a recent fire in Managua, he turned up in a fireman's suit, complete with...

byline.original: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Tomas Borge, the Nicaraguan Interior Minister, is a man of many public identities. Sometimes he appears in battle fatigues. Other times, he is dressed as a policeman. At a recent fire in Managua, he turned up in a fireman's suit, complete with rubber overcoat. Mr. Borge deports priests whenever he deems it necessary, but his official biography lists the Bible as his favorite book. He says he no longer considers himself a Roman Catholic, but he has accumulated a collection of crucifixes that fills an entire room.

results.snippet: * Arvin Industries, Columbus, Ind., which makes automotive, consumer and industrial products, has elected to its board Joseph P. Allen, executive vice president of Space Industries and a former astronaut with the National Aeronautics and Space...
results.lead_paragraph: * Arvin Industries, Columbus, Ind., which makes automotive, consumer and industrial products, has elected to its board Joseph P. Allen, executive vice president of Space Industries and a former astronaut with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. * Bamberger's, a Newark-based division of R.H. Macy & Co., has appointed Sankar Krishnan senior vice president and controller.

headline.main: Air Force Major to Take Part In a Secret Shuttle Mission

results.snippet: An Air Force major from New Jersey will join the astronauts next month on the military flight of the newest space shuttle, the Atlantis, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today. The agency is keeping the primary purpose of...
results.lead_paragraph: An Air Force major from New Jersey will join the astronauts next month on the military flight of the newest space shuttle, the Atlantis, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today. The agency is keeping the primary purpose of the mission secret.

headline.main: YOUNG SPACE ENTHUSIASTS CROWD ALABAMA CAMP

results.snippet: Television monitors flicker in the darkness inside Mission Control, where teen-agers wearing radio headsets crouched at consoles, pretending to guide the space shuttle Challenger to a landing at Cape Canaveral.   Twenty feet away, on the other side...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Television monitors flicker in the darkness inside Mission Control, where teen-agers wearing radio headsets crouched at consoles, pretending to guide the space shuttle Challenger to a landing at Cape Canaveral. Twenty feet away, on the other side of a wall, a second team of young people dressed in blue flight suits were buckled into seats inside a detailed reproduction of the shuttle's cockpit. After a simulated mission in space that lasted two and a half hours, they were bringing the orbiter home. Suddenly an adolescent voice came over the radio from Mission Control: ''Challenger, there's a 747 already on the runway in front of you. Please go back into orbit.''

results.snippet: To a visitor from the city, it's still summer in the Champagne region. The gardens are ablaze with brilliant dahlias and every window box is brimming over with geraniums and vivid petunias.   The men who tend the vines in this area know different....

byline.original: By Frank J. Prial, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: To a visitor from the city, it's still summer in the Champagne region. The gardens are ablaze with brilliant dahlias and every window box is brimming over with geraniums and vivid petunias. The men who tend the vines in this area know different. They point to ivy on the wall of an old church; the leaves are already deep red. And they see the shadows across the cobblestones of a winding courtyard, far longer at 6 P.M. than they were at that time a month ago.

headline.main: ART: THE SERIOUS WORK OF A NO-NONSENSE LEAR

results.snippet: ANYONE mildly good at ''Trivial Pursuit'' knows - if very little else about the man -that Edward Lear wrote ''The Owl and the Pussy-Cat,'' among many other deathless bits of English ephemera. Yet it was mainly as a painter - of flora, fauna and...
results.lead_paragraph: ANYONE mildly good at ''Trivial Pursuit'' knows - if very little else about the man -that Edward Lear wrote ''The Owl and the Pussy-Cat,'' among many other deathless bits of English ephemera. Yet it was mainly as a painter - of flora, fauna and landscapes - that Lear made a reputation during his lifetime (1812-1888), and it was as a painter that he wanted to be remembered. When he died, this versatile workaholic managed to leave more than 300 oils, thousands of watercolors, two books of natural history illustrations, and more than 100 lithographs of birds - all this besides published travel and ''Nonsense'' books, manuscripts, songs, diaries and a wealth of amusingly illustrated letters to friends. The growing interest in the 19th century, and the approaching centenary of Lear's birth, prompted the Royal Academy of Arts - lukewarm to Lear in his lifetime - to mount the first full survey of his work earlier this summer in London. Originally a show of some 300 objects from every turn of this close-packed career, it's been somewhat pruned - but none the worse for it - for its only American stop, at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street (through Nov. 3).

results.snippet: VICKI SELTZER of Old Westbury is traveling these days in the company of Elizabeth Swados, Carol Bellamy and Sally Ride. That is not to suggest that the 36-year-old Dr. Seltzer is working on a new musical for Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare...
results.lead_paragraph: VICKI SELTZER of Old Westbury is traveling these days in the company of Elizabeth Swados, Carol Bellamy and Sally Ride. That is not to suggest that the 36-year-old Dr. Seltzer is working on a new musical for Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival, running for mayor of New York or planning a new venture in outer space. But like the poet-lyricist, the City Council President and the astronaut before her, Dr. Seltzer, an obstetrician and gynecologist, holds a Young Woman Achiever Award from the National Council of Women. ''Basically,'' said Dr. Seltzer, who received the award in June, not long before her birthday, ''it's for woman who have contributed to their professions and their community and have made significant contributions by the time they're 35.''

results.snippet: The crew of the space shuttle Atlantis breezed through a dress-rehearsal countdown today to set the stage for the ship's maiden blastoff Oct. 3 on a classified military mission.
results.lead_paragraph: The crew of the space shuttle Atlantis breezed through a dress-rehearsal countdown today to set the stage for the ship's maiden blastoff Oct. 3 on a classified military mission.

headline.main: WHEN IT COMES TO MOVIES, THE WORLD LOOKS TO AMERICA

results.snippet: A recent issue of Le Point, a leading French news magazine, carried on its cover a full-page illustration for a story on ''Culture: How to Resist America.'' The bottom half of the illustration shows a besieged European continent with tiny figures...
results.lead_paragraph: A recent issue of Le Point, a leading French news magazine, carried on its cover a full-page illustration for a story on ''Culture: How to Resist America.'' The bottom half of the illustration shows a besieged European continent with tiny figures of d'Artagnan and Don Quixote girded for battle, supported, more or less, by a Rhine Maiden, Arlequino, Michaelangelo's David, the Parthenon, and Shakespeare's Globe Theater. Above, high in the sky, all-conquering, invincible, flies a United States astronaut, festooned with electronic equipment and bearing on his winglike arms Mickey Mouse, E.T., a cowboy and Marilyn Monroe. In actual fact, d'Artagnan and Don Quixote are losing. A glance at recent issues of Variety, the entertainment industry's trade journal, gives the general picture. A scattered sampling indicates that American films dominate the market in Paris, London, Stockholm, Copenhagen, Helsinki and Oslo. American movies hold 52.5 percent of the domestic market in Italy. Other parts of the world? Sylvester Stallone's ''Rambo,'' is running neck and neck with a Cantonese comedy in Hong Kong. In Australia, the same ''Rambo'' seems to be fending off a vigorous challenge from ''Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome,'' by all accounts the most successful film in Australian history. But it is Bill Murray's recording-breaking ''Ghostbusters'' that leads the pack for the first half of 1985 in Tokyo, where four of the top five films are American.

headline.main: Eastern Air Official Is Named President

results.snippet: Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday named Joseph B. Leonard, a 42-year-old engineer who has run the carrier's daily operations as executive vice president since May, to be president and chief operating officer.   As president, Mr. Leonard succeeds...

byline.original: By Kenneth N. Gilpin and Todd S. Purdum

results.lead_paragraph: Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday named Joseph B. Leonard, a 42-year-old engineer who has run the carrier's daily operations as executive vice president since May, to be president and chief operating officer. As president, Mr. Leonard succeeds Frank Borman, the 57-year-old former astronaut who remains chairman and chief executive of the Miami-based airline. The chief operating officer's post is a new one.
